content: This report summarizes the USDA's efforts to establish a national animal traceability system for rapid disease outbreak response. Despite economic benefits, federal proposals face opposition in the U.S. cattle industry. The report discusses background on animal ID and traceability, unresolved issues, and international standards. The USDA announced a new approach to animal disease traceability in 2010, replacing the National Animal Identification System. The new Animal Disease Traceability framework allows states to choose their own level of animal ID and traceability. However, all animals moving in interstate commerce must have traceable ID back to their originating state. Under the new Animal Disease Traceability framework, USDA will require all animals in interstate commerce to have traceable ID back to their originating state. A Traceability Regulation Working Group was established to gather feedback and make recommendations for a proposed rule. Public meetings were held to present the framework and gather feedback from animal health officials and producers. USDA's new framework for animal disease traceability involves public meetings to gather feedback from animal health officials and producers. The framework emphasizes that managing traceability is the responsibility of states and tribal nations, allowing states to choose their approach to animal ID and traceability. The revised framework for animal disease traceability allows states to choose their approach, including no mandatory animal ID, existing ID systems, or a detailed birth-to-market ID system. Within-state programs will be implemented by states and tribal nations, not the federal government. Federal rules will apply to livestock in interstate commerce, requiring official identification and an Interstate Certificate of Veterinary Inspection. Exemptions will be defined, and acceptable official identification types will be outlined in federal regulations. Performance standards for animal disease traceability will be evaluated through rulemaking. The animal disease traceability capacity of each state and tribal nation will be evaluated according to performance standards defined through rulemaking. Each state and tribal nation will have detailed traceability cooperative agreements with APHIS, with federal funding provided through annual cooperative agreements. No funding is designated for animal traceability in the agriculture appropriations bill for FY2011, but funding could be considered after needs are identified under USDA's new initiative. The USDA's new initiative will implement a program for animal disease traceability through federal regulations. A proposed rule could be published in April 2011, with a final rule expected 12 to 15 months later. The government aims to have all herds registered and cattle tagged by 2010, with traceability extended to all cuts of beef back to specific animals at their farm of origin. SNIG builds on Uruguay's national premises identification system (DICOSE) established in 1973. Uruguay's National Livestock Information System (SNIG) was implemented in 2006, building on the premises identification system established in 1973. SNIG includes premises and animal identification, movements, and termination data. The system does not currently require traceability to consumers, but this is being considered. Some countries like Bangladesh, India, Indonesia, and Russia do not have animal ID programs due to technological limitations and reliance on local production and marketing processes. Many countries with large agrarian populations lack national distribution chains for animal products, relying on local production and marketing. Lower-income consumers in poorer countries may not be willing to pay extra for traceable food.
